questions.text: Choose the one feature which is not defined under Edwards and Gross criteria (1976) for alcohol dependence syndrome.
questions.solution:
• Edwards and Gross criteria (1976) for alcohol dependence: 1. narrowed repertoire
  • salience of alcohol seeking behaviour
  • increased tolerance
  • repeated withdrawals
  • Drinking to prevent or relieve withdrawals.
  • subjective awareness of compulsion
  • reinstatement after abstinence

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 20: Substance use and addictive disorders - Alcohol related disorders.

questions.text: Global assessment of functioning forms which of the following axes in DSM-IV?
questions.solution:
• The multi-axial System of DSM-IV used 5 axes.
  • Axis I - Clinical Disorders.
  • Axis II - Personality Disorders/ Mental Retardation.
  • Axis III - General Medical Conditions.
  • Axis IV - Psychosocial and Environmental Problems.
  • Axis V - Global Assessment of Functioning. Note that DSM-5 has moved to a nonaxial system for diagnosis, with separate notations for crucial psychosocial factors (formerly Axis IV) and disability or impairment (formerly Axis V)

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 6: Classification in Psychiatry.

questions.text: Fugue state has been recognised as a type of
questions.solution:
• Psychogenic amnesia is usually caused by psychological factors. There are two types - global and situation specific. Fugue state is a type of psychogenic global amnesia in which there is a sudden loss of all autobiographical memories, knowledge of self and personal identity.
  • Usually, there is a period of wandering, and there is an amnesic gap upon recovery. It usually last a matter of hours or days. Memory recovers fully after few hours or days.

    Reference: Morgan and King Introduction to Psychology, 7th edition, Chapter 5: Memory.

choices.text: He has a specific phobia as he has an irrational fear
He has no specific phobia as fear of darkness is common
He has a specific phobia with loss of insight
He has no specific phobia as he does not have an avoidance behaviour

questions.text: A 25-year-old man has experienced an irrational fear of darkness since childhood. He is not distressed by this currently and does not take special measures to avoid dark spaces. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
• Specific phobias are restricted to highly specific situations such as proximity to certain animals, natural phenomenon such as heights, thunder, darkness, flying, being trapped in closed spaces, urinating or defecating in public toilets, eating certain foods, dentistry, or the sight of blood or injury.
  • The trigger is often discrete, but symptoms of anxiety are similar to panic attacks seen in other anxiety disorders

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 8: Anxiety disorders.

questions.text: Which one of the following has the worst prognosis among the subtypes of schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
• The onset of hebephrenic schizophrenia is insidious, usually in the early second decade. The course is often progressively downhill.
  • There is a rapid development of negative symptoms and disorganized behaviour. Severe deterioration without remission occurs over time. A recovery from the first episode rarely occurs in typical cases.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 7: Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

questions.text: Mr.Y is a 21-year-old gentleman who was admitted to a psychiatric inpatient unit 4 months ago. His clinical presentation includes inappropriate affect, senseless giggling, mirror-gazing for long periods of time, poor self-care and hygiene, marked thought disorder and severe loosening of association. He also exhibits fragmentary and changeable delusions and hallucinations. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hebephrenic schizophrenia is characterised by marked thought disorder and severe loosening of associations, Emotional disturbances characterised by inappropriate affect, blunted affect or senseless giggling, abnormal mannerisms like mirror gazing.
  • There is markedly impaired social and occupational functioning; poor self care, poor hygiene, extreme social behaviour and disorganized behaviour. ICD10 recommends a period of 2-3 months of continuous observation for making a confident diagnosis.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 7: Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

choices.text: Fear of abandonment and relying on other people
Increased sensitivity to criticism and setbacks

questions.text: Which of the following traits is seen in paranoid personality disorder?
questions.solution:
• Patients with paranoid traits are often combative and highly suspicious in nature; this may elicit a hostile response in others.
  • They are often critical of others, but have great difficulty in handling even a minor criticism from others.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 22: Personality disorders.

choices.text: The diagnosis can be made if there is a past history of bipolar disorder
Mood stabilizers are of no use in management
It is commonly associated with endocrine disturbances
Often fails to come to medical attention

questions.text: Which of the following is true concerning cyclothymia?
questions.solution:
• Cyclothymia is a mild form of episodic affective disorder characterized by the presence of numerous periods with hypomanic symptoms and numerous periods with depressive symptoms (not satisfying the criteria for a major depressive episode) for a period of at least 2 years.
  • Cyclothymia often fails to come to medical attention. After the initial 2 years (1 year in children and adolescents) required for a diagnosis of cyclothymic disorder, there may be superimposed manic or mixed episodes (in which case both bipolar I disorder and cyclothymic disorder may be diagnosed) or major depressive episodes (in which case both bipolar II disorder and cyclothymic disorder may be diagnosed).
  • Cyclothymic disorder often begins early in life. Lifetime prevalence rates for this disorder range between 0.4% and 1.0% in the general population, and between 3% and 5% in mood disorder clinics.
  • In community samples, the cyclothymic disorder is equally common in men and women, but women are more prevalent in clinical settings (in a ratio of approximately 3 to 2)

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 8: Mood disorders.

questions.text: Mr X is a 31-year-old gentleman who has suffered three manic episodes and 1 episode of depression in the past. He is already on antipsychotics and antidepressants. When reviewed in the out-patient clinic, he complains of low mood, frequent crying spells, poor concentration and lack of enjoyment in things he used to do. Which one of the following is the most appropriate medication for his condition?
questions.solution:
• This gentleman is suffering from bipolar depression which is a common and debilitating disorder which differs from unipolar disorder in severity, time, course, recurrence and response to drug treatment.
  • Episodes of bipolar depression are more rapid in onset, more severe, but often shorter in nature compared to unipolar depression.
  • Lamotrigine appears to be effective both as a treatment for bipolar depression and as a prophylaxis against further episodes.
  • It does not induce switching or rapid cycling. Antidepressant monotherapy is not recommended due to the risk of precipitating a switch to mania.

Reference: Stahl's Essential Psychopharmacology, 4th edition, Chapter 6: Mood disorders.

questions.text: Which one among the following is NOT a core diagnostic feature of ADHD?
questions.solution:
• The cardinal features of ADHD are excessive and impairing levels of activity, inattention, and impulsiveness. Hyperactivity-impulsivity symptoms include: fidgeting, moving, getting up and running about, talking excessively; unable to play quietly; continually interrupting.
  • Inattention symptoms include: being easily distracted, poor attention span and not able to sustain attention; poor task completion; inability to organize, and making mistakes with tasks that require attention; the child is forgetful, and often loses items of daily use.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 31: Child Psychiatry.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common clinical feature of mania?
questions.solution:
• The clinical features of mania includes elated, expansive mood that is not characteristic of the individual, irritability, physical over activity/restlessness, pressure of speech, flight of ideas, disturbed sleep or reduced need for sleep, increased libido, inflated self esteem, over spending, over-familiarity and psychotic symptoms.
  • Grandiose delusions are typical, auditory hallucinations and other delusions including first rank symptoms may also be present. It is equally common in men and women. The mean age of onset is in the early 20's.
  • The earlier the onset perhaps, the greater the genetic loading. It is more common in urban areas and equally distributed among the social classes. The lifetime risk of bipolar disorder is about 1%.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 8: Mood disorders.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman often falls asleep during the day. She has fallen asleep while speaking to her manager twice, causing problems at work. Her night time sleep is undisturbed, and other spheres of functioning are satisfactory. Physical health is unremarkable except for a history of an episode of fall 2 weeks ago when she was on a train laughing heartily with her boyfriend. She did not sustain any head injury then. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis for this case ?
questions.solution:
• Narcolepsy is characterised by the presence of both cataplexy and daytime sleepiness. Emotional stimuli such as laughter, startle, excitement, or anger can precipitate catalepsy.
  • They tend to fall due loss of tone in anti-gravity muscles of the legs. However, most attacks are mild and last only a few seconds.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 16: Normal sleep and sleep wake disorders.

questions.text: Mr.X is a 29-year-old gentleman who has a 6 month history of persecutory delusions about being spied on at home by his neighbours. There is no evidence of functional impairment. There is no history of past psychiatric illness or substance misuse. His most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Persistent delusional disorder is a category in ICD 10 that includes all disorders in which persistent delusions are the prominent and most important clinical features and delusions must be present for at least 3 months.
  • It includes delusions of persecution, delusions of grandeur, delusions of jealousy, somatic delusions or other non-bizarre delusions.
  • There should be a clear absence of significant or persistent hallucination and absence of organic mental disorders, schizophrenia and mood disorders.

Very often, the individuals carry on near normal and social and occupational life without arousing suspicion regarding the delusional disorder.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 7: Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following personality types is classified as a Cluster A personality disorder?
questions.solution:
• Paranoid, schizoid and schizotypal personality disorders are classified under cluster A.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 22: Personality disorders.

questions.text: Most children with selective mutism also meet diagnostic criteria for which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
• Selective mutism is a disorder characterized by persistent failure to speak in specific settings (school) despite full use of language at home or with family, may be found in younger children with social phobia.
  • Selective mutism appears to be more common in girls than in boys. Approximately 68% of children with selective mutism also meet diagnostic criteria for social phobia.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 31: Child Psychiatry.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of narcolepsy?
questions.solution:
• The cardinal symptoms of narcolepsy include excessive daytime drowsiness with sudden onset of REM sleep, often accompanied by cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone, provoked by strong emotion). Sleep paralysis and hypnagogic hallucinations may also occur albeit less commonly.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 16:

Normal sleep and sleep-wake disorders.

choices.text: Specific EEG changes occur in chronic PTSD
Previous history of neurotic illness precludes the development of PTSD features
PTSD symptoms usually occur within 6 months of the perceived trauma

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding PTSD is true?
questions.solution:
• PTSD symptoms usually occur within 6 months of the perceived trauma. The essential features are autonomic hyper arousal, re-experiencing of aspects of the stressful event and active avoidance of cues that remind of the trauma.
  • Anhedonia may also be seen; dramatic acute bursts of anxiety may present as exaggerated startle and hyper arousal. Insomnia is common. Predisposing factors include maladaptive personality traits (e.g. anankastic) or previous history of neurotic illnesses.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 11: Trauma and stress related disorders.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with suspected multiple sclerosis presents with loss of function in one arm. She does not seem concerned by this defect. This is best described as
questions.solution:
• La belle indifference is a surprising lack of concern for, or denial of, apparently severe functional disability. It is often seen in patients with hysteria and medical illness e.g. a cerebrovascular accident. It is a rare and non-specific symptom of no diagnostic value.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 13: Psychosomatic medicine.

questions.text: A man who has always had an anxious disposition has been feeling increasingly on the edge, has symptoms of breathlessness, chest pain and nausea that are worsening over the last 6 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by prominent tension, excessive worry with generalized free-floating persistent anxiety and feelings of apprehension about everyday events leading to significant stress and functional impairment. Physical symptoms and features of autonomic arousal are usually seen in GAD.
  • The ICD-10 list contains 22 physical symptoms of anxiety while there are only 6 in the DSM-5 list. Common physical symptoms include breathing difficulties, choking sensations, chest pain, nausea/abdominal distress.
  • The symptoms of autonomic arousal include sweating, palpitations, trembling and dry mouth.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 9: Anxiety disorders.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman becomes very tearful when her husband has to travel for work to a different place temporarily as she thinks she is unable to function without him. This is a feature of
questions.solution:
• Features of dependent personality disorder- assumes a position of passivity, allowing others to assume responsibility for most areas of their daily life, lack self-confidence, feel unable to function independently of another person, feels own needs are of secondary importance.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 22: Personality disorders.

choices.text: Liability to outbursts of anger or violence

questions.text: Which of the following features are noted in emotionally unstable personality- borderline type?
questions.solution:
• Emotionally unstable personality disorder (EUPD) is characterised by a marked tendency to act impulsively without consideration of the consequences, together with affective instability.
  • Two variants of this personality disorder are specified in ICD10, and both share this general theme of impulsiveness and lack of self-control. In the impulsive type, the predominant characteristics are emotional instability and lack of impulse control.
  • Outbursts of violence or threatening behaviour are common, particularly in response to criticism by others. In the borderline type, in addition to emotional instability, the patient's own self-image, aims, and internal preferences (including sexual) are often unclear or disturbed. There are usually chronic feelings of emptiness.
  • A liability to become involved in intense and unstable relationships may cause repeated emotional crises and may be associated with excessive efforts to avoid abandonment and a series of suicidal threats or acts of self-harm (although these may occur without obvious precipitants).

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 22: Personality disorders.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man moved from London to Dundee, a month ago. He is complaining of uneasiness, difficult to concentrate and a feeling of inability to cope since the move. The diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Adjustment disorder is a state of subjective distress and emotional disturbance, usually interfering with social functioning and performance, arising in the period of adaptation to a significant life change or to the consequences of a stressful life event.
  • It usually occurs within 1 month of the stressful event, and the duration of symptoms does not usually exceed 6 months.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 11: Trauma and stress related disorders.

questions.text: Attachment behaviour typically peaks between
questions.solution:
• Attachment behaviour is that displayed by the infant towards the attachment figure usually but not necessarily the mother. In the first few months, an infant orientates without discrimination, But by 5-7 months, the infant preferentially orientates and signals to discriminated persons.
  • Separation protest is observable by 7-9 months. By 9 months, the onset of attachment and stranger anxiety could be seen.
  • Attachment behaviour peaks between 12-18 months, and lessens by school age where the relationship is based more on abstract considerations such as affection, approval rather than on proximity maintenance.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 2: Contribution of Psychosocial Sciences.

questions.text: According to Margaret Mahler, the separation individuation phase lasts from
questions.solution:
• Separation-individuation phase lasts from 5 months to 5 years of age. It is further subdivided into; a)Differentiation sub phase: (5 to 10m) slowly appreciates the difference between mother and self
  • b)Practicing sub-phase: (10 to18m) gradual increase in interest on the environment; practices exploration.
  • C)Rapprochement sub-phase: (18 to 24m) Alternating drives to be autonomous and dependent; Able to explore alone but requires comfort and reassurance on return.
  • D) Object constancy sub-phase: (2 to 5yrs) Understand that the mother will not be lost if temporarily away; hence able to function independently

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 2: Contribution of Psychosocial Sciences.

questions.text: What is the most sensitive period for development of attachment behaviour in human beings?
questions.solution:
• According to Bowlby, attachment develops in the latter part of infancy, in the period from six to eighteen months. Attachment behaviour peaks between 12-18 months.
  • After this period, the attachment gets stabilized, and disruption of the bond is likely to lead to deleterious effects. Although infancy may be the optimal time to develop attachment, it has been shown that children adopted at four years are also capable of developing last lasting attachment to their adoptive parents (Tizard and Hodges 1978).

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 2: Contribution of Psychosocial Sciences.

questions.text: Imprinting is characterised by
questions.solution:
• Imprinting was first described by Konrad Lorenz following experiments on ducks and geese and described it as a specialized form of early learning and an example of an innate predisposition to acquire specific information.
  • Imprinting is characteristic of primate development and is also observed in birds. Imprinting is characterised by irreversibility, sensitive period, specificity and life-long retention.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 3: Contribution of Sociocultural Sciences.

questions.text: In which psychiatric disorder, up to three quarters of patients report physical or sexual abuse and prolonged separation form parents in early childhood?
questions.solution:
• Poor quality of caregiving in the form of neglect, abuse, separation, rejection and disrupted parenting is associated with most forms of psychopathology ranging from depression to personality disorders.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 22: Personality disorders.

choices.text: Wire mesh surrogate mother irrespective of feeding
Wire mesh surrogate mother that dispenses milk
Soft cloth surrogate mother that provides food
Soft cloth surrogate mother irrespective of feeding

questions.text: In Harlow's rhesus monkey studies, orphaned baby monkeys show a preference for clinging to a
questions.solution:
• Harlow's experiments: These experiments established the importance of contact comfort as basic as need for food in developing mother-infant bonding. Harlow separated rhesus monkeys from their mothers during their first weeks of life.
  • Harlow substituted a surrogate mother made from wire or cloth for the real mother. The infants preferred the cloth-covered surrogate mother, which provided contact comfort, to the wire-covered surrogate, which provided no contact comfort.
  • This preference was observed irrespective of feeding, i.e. the terry-cloth soft-surrogate mother was preferred even if it did not have a feeding nipple attached to it.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 3:

Contribution of Sociocultural Sciences.

questions.text: What are the three components of psychic functioning defined in Freud's structural theory?
questions.solution:
• Freud developed the idea of distinguishing mental events on the basis of their accessibility to conscious awareness. This early, 'topographic,' theory of the mind was elaborated in 1900 in his book Interpretation of Dreams. With 'The Ego and the Id', (1923) Freud subsumed the topographic concepts Conscious, Preconscious, and Unconscious into the 'structural' concepts Ego, Id, and Superego.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 4: Theories of personality and psychopathology.

questions.text: When a mother leaves an infant, the infant can become upset. To compensate and comfort for this sense of loss, an object with the attributes of the mother is required. Winnicott called these objects
questions.solution:
• Winnicott described transitional objects that are inanimate objects that may be a blanket or teddy bear that the child uses to provide oral/tactile comfort in dealing with the anxieties inherent in the task of separation and acceptance of reality and allows a child to become more independent of the mother.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 4: Theories of personality and psychopathology.

questions.text:
Match the following example to their most appropriate schizophrenia type used to explain them:
1.A 30 year old man develops a belief that his neighbours are spying on him and he hears them talking about him through the walls. He tells you that the television sends messages to him warning him about their plan to kidnap him.
2.A 25 year old man has a 10 year history of isolation and lack of attention to personal hygiene. He is unmotivated but lacks other symptoms of depression. He does not experience delusional beliefs or hallucinations.
3.A 17 year old girl is referred with a one year history of laughing without reason, inappropriate emotional responses, and disorganised behaviour
questions.solution:
• Paranoid schizophrenia is characterised by the preoccupation of delusions or hallucinations (typically persecutory or grandiose ones)
  • Disorganized schizophrenia (aka hebephrenic) is characterised by a regression to a primitive, unorganized form of behaviour. Incongruous behaviour such as grinning is common.
  • Catatonic schizophrenia is characterised by marked disturbances in motor function such as stupor, posturing, and rigidity.
  • Residual schizophrenia refers to patients who lack active psychotic symptoms but still have milder symptoms such as emotional blunting, and mild loosening of association.
  • Simple schizophrenia is characterised by predominately negative symptoms of schizophrenia in the absence of overtly psychotic experiences.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 7: Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered to be a mental or behavioural disorder by the ICD-10?
questions.solution:
• There is much debate regarding the aetiology of chronic fatigue syndrome. It is classified as a disease of the nervous system in the ICD-10 thus implying a physical causation. It shares much in common with neurasthenia and the two have much overlap.
  • Combat fatigue is an acute stress reaction, which is a transient reaction to stress lasting usually only a few days.
  • Grief reaction is considered to be an adjustment disorder, which is a state of subjective distress which occurs following a significant life event.
  • Ganser syndrome is a dissociative disorder, which occurs in prisoners. It is also known as prison psychosis and is not generally thought to be a factitious disorder. Affected individuals tend to give absurd answers to simple questions.
  • Neurasthenia is a condition characterized by excessive fatigue following either mental or physical effort. This is often accompanied by other unpleasant symptoms such as dizziness and tension headaches.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
• The epidemiological data on schizophrenia varies widely. Below are some important studies and their findings. You need to have an idea of the values. It is import to recognise however that compared to findings from other multifactorial conditions such as heart disease the magnitude of the differences across the studies is relatively small.

Prevalence

In a review of recent studies, Jablensky (2000) placed the prevalence rate in the range of 1.4-4.6 per thousand.

Incidence

Eaton (1999) presented data from 27 studies of schizophrenia published since 1985. The median incidence rate was 0.16 per thousand which was lower than previously reported.

Gender

The male female ratio is 1:1.

Course and prognosis

Schizophrenia is a chronic condition that tends to take a deteriorating course. The longer the follow up extends, the proportion classed as having a good outcome becomes the smaller. Many studies find that younger patients, males, and those with a positive family history have the worst outcome. Failure to comply with treatment has been shown to be one of the strongest predictors of relapse. Ram (1992) concluded that over a 2 year period, one-third of patients with schizophrenia showed a benign course, and two-thirds either relapsed or failed to recover. People with schizophrenia have a 2-3 fold increased risk of premature death (SMR all cause mortality 2.5).

Winter births

Winter births are associated with an increased risk of schizophrenia. Urbanicity There is a higher incidence associated with urbanicity.

Migration

There is a higher incidence associated with migration.

Class

Higher prevalence among lower socio-economic class.

Learning disability

Prevalence rates for schizophrenia in people with learning disabilities are approximately three times greater than for the general population (3% vs 1%)

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 7: Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for suicide?
questions.solution:
Risk factors for suicide include:-

Male gender

Unemployment

Concurrent mental disorders

Previous suicide attempt

Substance misuse

Low socio-economic status.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 23: Emergency Psychiatric Medicine.

questions.text: A patient with known hyperlipidaemia develops a psychotic illness. Which of the following antipsychotics has the least effect on the lipid profile and so should be considered in this case?
questions.solution:
• The majority of antipsychotics have an effect on lipid profile. Regarding the evidence available on the second generation antipsychotics, olanzapine and clozapine appear to increase lipids the most, followed by quetiapine, and then risperidone. Aripiprazole and ziprasidone seem to have minimal effects on lipids.

Reference: Stahl's Essential Psychopharmacology, 4th edition, Chapter 4.

questions.text:
Select the appropriate personality disorder described in each scenario given below:
1. A young woman comes to see you complaining of uncontrollable mood swings, an intolerance of being alone, and recent self harm.
2. A mother brings her 30 year old son to see you complaining that he is cold and aloof, has no friends, and seems indifferent to praise or criticism.
3. A female patient is referred by her GP. She complains bitterly about a new lady in her office who is getting too much attention. She appears vain and shallow, and seems to being trying to seduce you.
questions.solution:
Features of borderline personality disorder include:-

Efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment

Unstable interpersonal relationships which alternate between idealization and devaluation

Unstable self image

Impulsivity in potentially self damaging area (e.g. Spending, sex, substance abuse) Recurrent suicidal behaviour

Affective instability

Chronic feelings of emptiness

Difficulty controlling temper

Quasi psychotic thoughts.

Schizoid personality disorder is characterised by:-

Indifference to praise and criticism

Preference for solitary activities

Lack of interest in sexual interactions

Lack of desire for companionship

Emotional coldness

Few interests

Few friends or confidants other than family

Histrionic personality disorder is characterised by:-

Inappropriate sexual seductiveness

Need to be the centre of attention

Rapidly shifting and shallow expression of emotions

Suggestibility

Physical appearance used for attention seeking purposes

Impressionistic speech lacking detail

Self dramatization

Relationships considered to be more intimate than they are

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 22: Personality disorders.

questions.text: Who described the unconscious as composed of both the collective unconscious and personal unconscious?
questions.solution:
• Carl Gustav Jung described a holistic theory of psyche that can be applied across varied cultures. According to him, the unconscious mind includes the collective and personal unconscious.
  • He postulated that the personal unconscious is unique to each individual, but the collective unconscious is universal, common to mankind, contains the archetypes that include anima, animus, shadow or self and Hero.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 4: Theories of personality and psychopathology.

questions.text: A young man brings his 19-year-old girl friend who vacantly stares at the wall, not responding to the conversation. He reports that she started behaving in this manner since they had a serious argument. The most likely defence mechanism operating here is
questions.solution:
• In general, dissociation includes day dreaming, 'zoning out,' or doing things on 'autopilot.' For example, staring out during lectures and thinking what to do in the evening, driving a car and not able to describe what you saw on the way are some daily examples of dissociation.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 4: Theories of personality and psychopathology.

questions.text: Which of the following was employed by Freud as a psychoanalytic technique to uncover the unconscious?
questions.solution:
• Using the technique of free association, Freud asked patients to relate anything that came into their mind, regardless of how apparently unimportant or potentially embarrassing the memory threatened to be.
  • This technique assumed that all memories are arranged in a single associative network and that sooner or later the subject would stumble across the crucial memory.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 4: Theories of personality and psychopathology.

choices.text: It is governed by the reality principle

questions.text: Which one of the following is true about the Ego?
questions.solution:
• The Id is the most primitive part of the personality and it is instinctive, unconsciously motivated and is governed by the pleasure principle.
  • The Ego is consciously driven, governed by the reality principle and contains reality-oriented parts of the self. The ego is largely conscious.
  • The superego is formed by introjects of parental figures. The superego has both conscious and unconscious aspects, and can be equated to the conscience of the individual.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 4: Theories of personality and psychopathology.

questions.text: Oedipus complex and castration anxiety are associated with which stages of psychosexual development?
questions.solution:
• Phallic/oedipal stage is seen between 3 and five years of age during which the child increasingly focuses on genitalia and libido is directed towards others. His stage involves castration anxiety and Oedipus complex in males and penis envy and Electra complex in females.
  • The Oedipal complex refers to the intense attachment to the parents of the opposite sex along with a wish to destroy the parents of the same sex. Resolution of the Oedipal complex involves identification with the same sex parent (i.e. the son identifying with the father).

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 4: Theories of personality and psychopathology.

questions.text: Which one among the following is considered as a mature defence mechanism?
questions.solution:
• Primitive/immature defenses include splitting, projection, projective identification, idealization, denigration, introjection, passive aggression and turning against the self.
  • Neurotic defence include repression, regression, denial, displacement, dissociation, isolation, reaction formation, intellectualization, rationalization, externalization and identification with the aggressor.
  • Humour, anticipation, sublimation, altruism and suppression (SASHA) are all mature defence mechanisms.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 4: Theories of personality and psychopathology.

questions.text: The drug 'khat' (Catha edulis) has effects comparable to
questions.solution:
• Cathinone is an alkaloid present in the leaves of the khat bush that grows in East Africa and southern Arabia and is often chewed because of its stimulating properties.
  • Cathinone, which is S(-)-alpha-aminopropiophenone, has a pharmacological profile closely resembling that of amphetamine; indeed, in a wide variety of in vitro and in vivo experiments it was demonstrated that cathinone shares the action of amphetamine on CNS as well as its sympathomimetic effects; thus, for example, drug conditioned animals will not distinguish between cathinone and amphetamine. It operates through the same mechanism as amphetamine; i.e. it acts by releasing catecholamine's from presynaptic storage sites.
  • Thus, much experimental evidence indicates that cathinone is the main psychoactive constituent of the khat leaf and that, in fact, this alkaloid is a natural amphetamine.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 20: Substance use and addictive disorders.

Excerpt from Cathinone, a natural amphetamine. Retrieved fromhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1508843

choices.text: Increased levels of choline acetyl transferase

questions.text: The neurochemical changes reported in Alzheimer's disease include
questions.solution:
• The neurochemical changes reported in Alzheimer's disease would include decreased levels of acetylcholinesterase, decreased levels of choline acetyltransferase, decreased GABA levels and decreased levels of noradrenaline.

Reference: Stahl's Essential Psychopharmacology, 4th edition, Chapter 13.

questions.text: Which one of the following is an incorrect pairing of the disease condition and the primary neurotransmitter that is abnormal in the diseases?
questions.solution:
• Dopamine is implicated in both schizophrenia and Parkinson's disease. Glutamate is implicated in many neurodegenerative disorders while GABA is implicated in epilepsy. Both noradrenaline and serotonin are relevant for depression and anxiety.
  • Acetylcholine is more relevant than dopamine for Alzheimer's dementia. Please note that the explanation here is an over-simplification - most neuropsychiatric disorders include a generalized disturbance in multiple neurotransmission systems.

Reference: Stahl's Essential Psychopharmacology, 4th edition, Chapter 1, 2, 3, 4, 9, 13.

questions.text: The effects of magic mushroom are very similar to those of
questions.solution:
• Many hallucinogens occur naturally in 'magic mushrooms', datura or 'angel's trumpet' (atropine-like effects), mescaline and DMT (dimethyltryptamine). Magic mushrooms contain two hallucinogenic substances: psilocin and psilocybin.
  • Psilocybin gets converted to psilocin and acts similar to LSD, although it is about 100 times less potent than the synthetic LSD itself. The most popular hallucinogen in current use is the synthetic drug LSD.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 20: Substance use and addictive disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following receptors is stimulated when tobacco is smoked?
questions.solution:
• Nicotine acts on nicotinic cholinergic receptors.

Reference: Stahl's Essential Psychopharmacology, 4th edition, Chapter 14.

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitters are not correctly matched with their precursors?
questions.solution:
• The biosynthesis of catecholamine's starts from the conversion of tyrosine into Ldihydroxyphenylalanine (L-DOPA) by tyrosine hydroxylase. L-DOPA is then decarboxylated by DOPA decarboxylase to form dopamine.
  • The conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine comes about by the action of the enzyme dopamine ß-hydroxylase. The rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of serotonin is tryptophan hydroxylase.
  • Here, tryptophan is converted to 5- hydroxytryptophan by tryptophan hydroxylase and by 5-hydroxytryptophan decarboxylase into serotonin. Histidine is the precursor of histamine not serotonin.

Reference: Stahl's Essential Psychopharmacology, 4th edition, Chapter 1, 2, 3.

choices.text: It is not seen as an isolated phenomenon
The belief can be held with delusional fixity
It is more common in women than men

questions.text: Which of the following is true concerning the psychopathology of morbid jealousy?
questions.solution:
• Morbid jealousy can occur as an isolated state but can also occur in association with alcohol or cocaine misuse, impotence, schizophrenia, mania, depression, organic conditions like dementia, and terminal stages of alcoholism and punch-drunk syndrome. Male to female ratio is 3:1.

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, 4th edition, Chapter 4: Disorders of Thought and Speech.

questions.text: You are interviewing a newly admitted patient in your ward. When asked what he had for breakfast, he says 'cereals'. Then when you asked 'what is your name?' he says 'cereals'. When you asked 'what is his date of birth?' he continues to say 'cereals'. The most likely symptom exhibited here is
questions.solution:
• Perseveration occurs when mental operations persist beyond the point at which they are relevant and thus prevent progress of thinking. Perseveration may be mainly verbal or ideational.
  • Verbal perseveration can be a perseveration of theme rather than the actual words and this can be regarded as impairment of switching. In other cases the set or attitude is perseverated, and the patient cannot solve a new problem because they cannot break free from their previous set. Verbal perseveration can occur in schizophrenia and organic states.

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, 4th edition, Chapter 4: Disorders of Thought and Speech.
